direct_answer.text:
To determine when Carlos begins making profit from selling the lemons produced by the tree, we need to calculate whether or not his income exceeds his cost (the initial purchase price plus any recurring maintenance fees). Let’s break it down per year:

Carlos buys the tree for $90 initially. Each subsequent year adds another revenue stream through the sale of individual lemons while also increasing his outflow due to the upkeep fee ($3/year) but no additional purchasing costs since the tree already exists. We want to know until these revenues offset all accumulated costs including both buyout and maintenance over time. Therefore, let us establish an equation representing net earnings based upon 'x', denoting years elapsed post-purchase; i.e., Revenue – Cost >= Net Profit:
Revenue generated annually comes from multiplying Lemon production volume (yield), which remains constant every year as long as you don’t take into account natural variations such like disease etc., times Sell Price Per Unit : 2256855*1.5=$3385282.5    --(Condition 2 & 3 combined)

Carlos initially invests $90 into buying one lemon tree. Each lemon tree produces about 2256855 lemons per year, which can be sold individually for $1.5 apiece. Annual Lemon Production: ~2256855 lemons/year
Price Per Lemon: $1.5/lemon -> Revenue From Selling All Produced Lemons : 2256855*$1.5=$3385282.5
First Year Cost: Purchase Price + Maintenance = $90+$3=$93
Second Year Cost: Only Need Consider Maintenance as already purchased the Tree => $3
Cumulative Profit Until Second Harvest Endorsement :: ((Revenue From First Harvest + Third Harvest )-(Cost Of First Yrs And Restoring Trees)) // No Loss Or Surplus Assumed
